As an implicit response to EARN IT, Wyden along with House Representative [[Anna G. Eshoo]] proposed a new bill, the Invest in Child Safety Act, in May 2020 that would give {{USD|5 billion}} to the Department to Justice to give additional manpower and tools to enable them to address child exploitation directly rather than to rely on technology companies to rein in the problem.{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/us/child-abuse-legislation.html | title = A $5 Billion Proposal to Fight Online Child Sexual Abuse | first = Michael | last = Keller | date = May 5, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[The New York Times]] | archive-date = February 5, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210205193147/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/05/us/child-abuse-legislation.html | url-status = live }} :The EARN IT Act advanced out of the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|senate judiciary committee]] by a unanimous 22-0 vote on July 2, 2020, following an amendment by Lindsey Graham. Graham's amendment removed the legal authority of the proposed federal commission, instead giving a similar authority to each individual state government.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/earn-it-act-amendments-pass-senate-judiciary-committee-165030518.html|title=EARN IT Act amendments transfer the fight over Section 230 to the states|work=[[Engadget]]|first=Christine|last=Fisher|date=July 2, 2020|access-date=September 16, 2020|archive-date=January 26, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210126234313/https://www.engadget.com/earn-it-act-amendments-pass-senate-judiciary-committee-165030518.html|url-status=live}} The bill was introduced into the House on October 2, 2020.{{cite web | url = https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2020/10/urgent-earn-it-act-introduced-house-representatives | title = Urgent: EARN IT Act Introduced in House of Representatives | first = Joe | last = Mullin | date = October 2, 2020 | access-date = October 2, 2020 | work = [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]] | archive-date = February 23, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210223043742/https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2020/10/urgent-earn-it-act-introduced-house-representatives | url-status = live }} ;Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Act :In June 2020, Hawley and three Republican Senators, [[Marco Rubio]], [[Kelly Loeffler]] and [[Kevin Cramer]], called on the FCC to review the protections that the Big Tech companies had from Section 230, stating in their letter that "It is time to take a fresh look at Section 230 and to interpret the vague standard of 'good faith' with specific guidelines and direction" due to the "a lack of clear rules" and the "judicial expansion" around the statute.{{cite web | url = https://www.nationalreview.com/news/gop-senators-ask-fcc-to-clearly-define-section-230-protections-for-big-tech/ | title = GOP Senators Ask FCC to 'Clearly Define' Section 230 Protections for Big Tech | first = Tobias | last = Hoonhout | date = June 9, 2020 | access-date = June 14, 2020 | work = [[National Review]] | archive-date = August 7, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200807024809/https://www.nationalreview.com/news/gop-senators-ask-fcc-to-clearly-define-section-230-protections-for-big-tech/ | url-status = live }} Hawley introduced the "Limiting Section 230 Immunity to Good Samaritans Act" bill in the Senate on June 17, 2020, with co-sponsors Rubio, [[Mike Braun]] and [[Tom Cotton]], which would allow providers with over 30 million monthly U.S. users and over {{USD|1.5 billion}} in global revenues to be liable to lawsuits from users who believed that the provider was not uniformly enforcing content; users would be able to seek damages up to {{USD|5000}} and lawyers fees under the bill.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/17/21294032/section-230-hawley-rubio-conservative-bias-lawsuit-good-faith | title = Senate Republicans want to make it easier to sue tech companies for bias | first = Russell | last = Brandom | date = June 17, 2020 | access-date = June 17, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = February 20, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210220163637/https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/17/21294032/section-230-hawley-rubio-conservative-bias-lawsuit-good-faith | url-status = live }} ;Platform Accountability and Consumer Transparency (PACT) Act :A bi-partisan bill introduced by Senators [[Brian Schatz]] and [[John Thune]] in June 2020, the "Platform Accountability and Consumer Technology Act" would require Internet platforms to issue public statements on their policies for how they moderate, demonetize, and remove user content from their platforms, and to publish public quarterly reports to summarize their actions and statistics for that quarter. The bill would also mandate that platforms conform with all court-ordered removal of content deemed illegal within 24 hours. Further, the bill would eliminate platforms' Section 230 protections from federal civil liability in cases brought against the platforms and would enable states' attorney generals to enforce actions against platforms. Schatz and Thune considered their approach more of "a scalpel, rather than a jackhammer" in contrast to other options that have been presented to date.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/24/21302170/facebook-google-brian-schatz-john-thune-section-230-content-moderation | title = The PACT Act would force platforms to disclose shadowbans and demonetizations | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = June 24, 2020 | access-date = June 24, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = February 20, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210220163633/https://www.theverge.com/2020/6/24/21302170/facebook-google-brian-schatz-john-thune-section-230-content-moderation | url-status = live }} ;Behavioral Advertising Decisions Are Downgrading Services (BAD ADS) Act :Hawley introduced the Behavioral Advertising Decisions Are Downgrading Services Act in July 2020, which would remove Section 230 protections for larger service providers (30 million users in the U.S. or 300 million globally and with more than {{USD|1.5 billion}} in annual revenue) if their sites used [[behavioral advertising]], with ads tailored to the users of the sites based on how the users had engaged with the site or where they were located. Hawley had spoken out against such ad practices and had previously tried to add legislation to require service providers to add "do not track" functionality for Internet ads.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/7/28/21344894/josh-hawley-bad-ads-act-behavioral-advertising-bill-section-230 | title = Sen. Josh Hawley wants to strip legal protections from sites with targeted ads | first = Adi | last = Robinson | date = July 28, 2020 | access-date = July 28, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = January 25, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210125212629/https://www.theverge.com/2020/7/28/21344894/josh-hawley-bad-ads-act-behavioral-advertising-bill-section-230 | url-status = live }} ;Online Freedom and Viewpoint Diversity Act :Republican Senators Lindsey Graham, [[Roger Wicker]] and [[Marsha Blackburn]] introduced the Online Freedom and Viewpoint Diversity Act in September 2020. The bill, if passed, would strip away Section 230 liability protection for sites that fail to give reason for actions taken in moderating or restricting content, and require them to state that said content must have an "objectively reasonable belief" it violated their site's terms or the site could be penalized. The bill would also replace the vague "objectionable" term in Section 230(c)(2) with more specific categories, like "unlawful" material where a website would not become liable for taking steps to moderate content.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/8/21428079/republicans-pressure-platforms-230-bill-liability-protection-blackburn-lindsey-graham-wicker | title = Republicans pressure platforms with new 230 bill | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = September 8, 2020 | access-date = September 8, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = February 28, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210228082730/https://www.theverge.com/2020/9/8/21428079/republicans-pressure-platforms-230-bill-liability-protection-blackburn-lindsey-graham-wicker | url-status = live }} ;Safeguarding Against Fraud, Exploitation, Threats, Extremism, and Consumer Harms Act (SAFE TECH act) :Democratic Senators Mark Warner, [[Mazie Hirono]] and Amy Klobuchar introduced the SAFE TECH in February 2021. The bill has multiple parts. It would first alter 230(c)(1) to cover only "speech" and not "information" making providers liable for illegal speech. It would also remove the Good Samaritan immunity around federal and state laws with regards to civil rights laws, antitrust laws, cyberstalking laws, human rights laws or civil actions regarding a wrongful death. Further, it would eliminate the immunity for any speech that the provider was paid to carry, such as through advertising or marketplace listings. Finally, it would force providers to comply with court orders for removal of material related to the prior areas.{{cite web | url = https://www.protocol.com/democrats-plan-section-230 | title = This is the Democrats' plan to limit Section 230 | first1 = Emily | last1 = Birnbaum | first2 = Issie | last2 = Lapowsky | date = February 5, 2021 | access-date = February 5, 2021 | work = [[Protocol (website)|Protocol]] | archive-date = February 9, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210209081258/https://www.protocol.com/democrats-plan-section-230 | url-status = live }} ====Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship==== President Donald Trump was a major proponent of limiting the protections of technology and media companies under Section 230 due to claims of an anti-conservative bias. In July 2019, Trump held a "Social Media Summit" that he used to criticize how Twitter, Facebook, and Google handled conservative voices on their platforms. During the summit, Trump warned that he would seek "all regulatory and legislative solutions to protect free speech".{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/07/11/we-will-not-let-them-get-away-with-it-trump-threatens-social-media-ahead-white-house-summit/ | title = Trump accuses social media companies of 'terrible bias' at White House summit decried by critics | first = Tony | last = Romm | date = July 11, 2019 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | newspaper = [[The Washington Post]] | archive-date = December 21, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201221133930/https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/07/11/we-will-not-let-them-get-away-with-it-trump-threatens-social-media-ahead-white-house-summit/ | url-status = live }} [[File:Donald J Trump (realDonaldTrump) Twitter - публикация от 2020-05-26.png|thumb|left|The two tweets on May 26, 2020, from President Trump that Twitter had marked "potentially misleading" (inserting the blue warning icon and "Get the facts..." language) that led to the executive order]] In late May 2020, President Trump made statements that [[Postal voting|mail-in voting]] would lead to massive fraud, in a pushback against the use of mail-in voting due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]] for the upcoming 2020 primary elections, in both his public speeches and his [[Donald Trump on social media|social media accounts]]. In a Twitter message on May 26, 2020, he stated that, "There is NO WAY (ZERO!) that Mail-In Ballots will be anything less than substantially fraudulent." Shortly after its posting, Twitter moderators marked the message with a "potentially misleading" warning (a process it had introduced a few weeks earlier that month primarily in response to misinformation about the COVID-19 pandemic){{cite web | url = https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/updating-our-approach-to-misleading-information.html | title = Updating our Approach to Misleading Information | first1 = Yoel | last1 = Roth | first2 = Nick | last2 = Pickles | date = May 11, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | publisher = [[Twitter]] | archive-date = February 28, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210228043728/https://blog.twitter.com/en_us/topics/product/2020/updating-our-approach-to-misleading-information.html | url-status = live }} linking readers to a special page on its site that provided analysis and fact-checks of Trump's statement from media sources like [[CNN]] and ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the first time it had used the process on Trump's messages.{{cite web | url = https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/27/app-politics-section/donald-trump-mail-in-voter-fraud-fact-check/index.html | title = Fact-checking Trump's recent claims that mail-in voting is rife with fraud | first1 = Holmes | last1 = Lybrand | first2 = Tara | last2 = Subramaniam | date = May 27, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[CNN]] | archive-date = February 28, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210228053711/https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/27/app-politics-section/donald-trump-mail-in-voter-fraud-fact-check/index.html | url-status = live }} [[Jack Dorsey]], Twitter's CEO, defended the moderation, stating that they were not acting as a "arbitrator of truth" but instead "Our intention is to connect the dots of conflicting statements and show the information in dispute so people can judge for themselves."{{cite web | url = https://thehill.com/policy/technology/499866-dorsey-defends-decision-to-fact-check-trump-tweet-more-transparency-from-us | title = Dorsey defends decision to fact-check Trump tweet: 'More transparency from us is critical' | first = Rebecca | last = Klar | date = May 28, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | archive-date = February 28, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210228013604/https://thehill.com/policy/technology/499866-dorsey-defends-decision-to-fact-check-trump-tweet-more-transparency-from-us | url-status = live }} Trump was angered by this, and shortly afterwards threatened that he would take action to "strongly regulate" technology companies, asserting these companies were suppressing conservative voices.{{cite web | url = https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/27/politics/donald-trump-twitter-threat-regulate/index.html | title = Trump threatens to crack down on social media platforms after Twitter labels his tweets | first = Brian | last = Fung | date = May 27, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[CNN]] | archive-date = January 21, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210121164932/https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/27/politics/donald-trump-twitter-threat-regulate/index.html | url-status = live }} [[File:President Trump Signs an Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship (49948964852).jpg|thumb|Trump signs an executive order on "Preventing Online Censorship" on May 28, 2020.]] On May 28, 2020, Trump signed the "Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship" (EO 13925), an [[List of executive actions by Donald Trump|executive order]] directing regulatory action at Section 230.{{cite web | url = https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-preventing-online-censorship/ | title = Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship | date = May 28, 2020 | via = [[NARA|National Archives]] | work = [[whitehouse.gov]] | access-date = May 28, 2020 | archive-date = January 29, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210129161142/https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/presidential-actions/executive-order-preventing-online-censorship/ | url-status = live }} Trump stated in a press conference before signing his rationale for it: "A small handful of social media monopolies controls a vast portion of all public and private communications in the United States. They've had unchecked power to censor, restrict, edit, shape, hide, alter, virtually any form of communication between private citizens and large public audiences." The EO asserts that media companies that edit content apart from restricting posts that are violent, obscene or harassing, as outlined in the "Good Samaritan" clause §230(c)(2), are then "engaged in editorial conduct" and may forfeit any safe-harbor protection granted in §230(c)(1).{{cite web |url=https://www.latimes.com/business/technology/story/2020-05-28/the-facts-about-section-230-the-internet-speech-law-trump-wants-to-change |title=The facts about Section 230, the internet speech law Trump wants to change |last=Dean |first=Sam |date=May 28, 2020 |website=Los Angeles Times |access-date=May 29, 2020 |archive-date=March 4, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210304013719/https://www.latimes.com/business/technology/story/2020-05-28/the-facts-about-section-230-the-internet-speech-law-trump-wants-to-change |url-status=live }} From that, the EO specifically targets the "Good Samaritan" clause for media companies in their decisions to remove offensive material "in good faith". Courts have interpreted the "in good faith" portion of the statute based on its plain language; the EO purports to establish conditions where that good faith may be revoked, such as if the media companies have shown bias in how they remove material from the platform. The goal of the EO is to remove the Section 230 protections from such platforms, thus leaving them liable for content.{{cite news | url = https://www.npr.org/2020/05/28/863932758/stung-by-twitter-trump-signs-executive-order-to-weaken-social-media-companies | title = Stung By Twitter, Trump Signs Executive Order To Weaken Social Media Companies | first = Bobby | last = Allyn | date = May 28, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[NPR]] | archive-date = June 28, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200628223529/https://www.npr.org/2020/05/28/863932758/stung-by-twitter-trump-signs-executive-order-to-weaken-social-media-companies | url-status = live }} Whether a media platform has bias would be determined by a rulemaking process to be set by the Federal Communications Commission in consultation with the Commerce Department, the [[National Telecommunications and Information Administration]] (NTIA), and the Attorney General, while the Justice Department and state attorneys general will handle disputes related to bias, gather these to report to the Federal Trade Commission, who would make determinations if a federal lawsuit should be filed. Additional provisions prevent government agencies from advertising on media company platforms that are demonstrated to have such bias.{{cite web | url= https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/28/politics/trump-twitter-social-media-executive-order/index.html | title= Trump is set to announce an executive order against social media companies | first1= Brian | last1= Fung | first2= Ryan | last2= Nobles | first3= Kevin | last3= Liptak | date= May 28, 2020 | access-date= May 28, 2020 | work= [[CNN]] | archive-date= February 13, 2021 | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210213142743/https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/28/politics/trump-twitter-social-media-executive-order/index.html | url-status= live }} [[File:Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship.pdf|thumb|right|upright|Text of the "Executive Order on Preventing Online Censorship"]] The EO came under intense criticism and legal analysis after its announcement.{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/28/us/politics/trump-jack-dorsey.html | title = Trump's Order on Social Media Could Harm One Person in Particular: Donald Trump | first1 = Peter | last1 = Baker | first2 = Daisuke | last2 = Wakabayashi | date = May 28, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[The New York Times]] | archive-date = May 28, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200528233019/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/05/28/us/politics/trump-jack-dorsey.html | url-status = live }} Senator Wyden stated that the EO was a "mugging of the First Amendment", and that there does need to be a thoughtful debate about modern considerations for Section 230, though the political spat between Trump and Twitter is not a consideration.{{cite web | url = https://www.fastcompany.com/90510815/trumps-new-executive-order-is-a-mugging-of-the-first-amendment-says-sen-wyden | title = Trump's new executive order is a 'mugging of the First Amendment,' says Sen. Wyden | first = Mark | last = Sullivan | date = May 28, 2020 | access-date = May 28, 2020 | work = [[Fast Company]] | archive-date = November 28, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201128234250/https://www.fastcompany.com/90510815/trumps-new-executive-order-is-a-mugging-of-the-first-amendment-says-sen-wyden | url-status = live }} Professor Kate Klonick of [[St. John's University School of Law]] in New York considered the EO "political theater" without any weight of authority. The Electronic Frontier Foundation's Aaron Mackey stated that the EO starts with a flawed misconstruing of linking sections §230(c)(1) and §230(c)(2), which were not written to be linked and have been treated by case law as independent statements in the statute, and thus "has no legal merit". By happenstance, the EO was signed on the same day that [[Twin Cities riots|riots]] erupted in Minneapolis, Minnesota in the wake of the [[murder of George Floyd]], an African-American from an incident involving four officers of the Minneapolis Police Department. Trump had tweeted on his conversation with Minnesota's governor [[Tim Walz]] about bringing [[National Guard]] to stop the riots, but concluded with the statement, "Any difficulty and we will assume control but, when the looting starts, the shooting starts", a phrase [[when the looting starts, the shooting starts|attached to Miami Police Chief Walter E. Headley to deal with violent riots in 1967]].{{cite web |last1=Torres |first1=Ella |last2=Mansell |first2=William |title=Minnesota protest updates: Trump warns military could 'assume control' of protest response |url=https://abcnews.go.com/US/dangerous-protests-erupt-overnight-george-floyds-death-minneapolis/story?id=70924047 |website=ABC News |date=May 29, 2020 |access-date=May 29, 2020 |archive-date=May 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200529023807/https://abcnews.go.com/US/dangerous-protests-erupt-overnight-george-floyds-death-minneapolis/story?id=70924047 |url-status=live }}{{cite web |last1=Madani |first1=Doha |title=Trump warns 'when looting starts, shooting starts' as fires burn in Minneapolis |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-s-warning-minneapolis-burns-over-george-floyd-s-death-n1217571 |website=NBC News |date=May 29, 2020 |access-date=May 29, 2020 |archive-date=May 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200529061039/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/trump-s-warning-minneapolis-burns-over-george-floyd-s-death-n1217571 |url-status=live }} After internal review, Twitter marked the message with a "public interest notice" that deemed it "glorified violence", which they would normally remove for violating the site's terms, but stated to journalists that they "have kept the Tweet on Twitter because it is important that the public still be able to see the Tweet given its relevance to ongoing matters of public importance."{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/twitter-donald-trumps-warning-label-minneapolis-glorifies-violence-1234619685/ | title = Twitter Adds Warning Label to Donald Trump's Tweet About 'Shooting' Protesters in Minneapolis, Saying It Glorifies Violence | first = Todd | last = Spangler | date = May 29, 2020 | access-date = May 29, 2020 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | archive-date = March 2, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210302201434/https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/twitter-donald-trumps-warning-label-minneapolis-glorifies-violence-1234619685/ | url-status = live }} Following Twitter's marking of his May 28 tweet, Trump said in another tweet that due to Twitter's actions, "Section 230 should be revoked by Congress. Until then, it will be regulated!"{{cite web | url = https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/500078-trump-accuses-twitter-of-unfair-targeting-after-company-labels-tweet | title = Trump accuses Twitter of unfair targeting after company labels tweet 'glorifying violence' | first = Morgan | last = Chalfant | date = May 29, 2020 | access-date = May 29, 2020 | work = [[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] | archive-date = May 29, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20200529190726/https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/500078-trump-accuses-twitter-of-unfair-targeting-after-company-labels-tweet | url-status = live }} By June 2, 2020, the [[Center for Democracy & Technology]] filed a lawsuit in the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]] seeking preliminary and permanent injunction from the EO from being enforced, asserting that the EO created a [[chilling effect]] on free speech since it puts all hosts of third-party content "on notice that content moderation decisions with which the government disagrees could produce penalties and retributive actions, including stripping them of Section 230's protections".{{cite web | url = https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/trump-sued-over-social-media-executive-order-first-amendment-1234623504/ | title = Lawsuit Alleges Donald Trump's Executive Order Targeting Twitter, Facebook Violates First Amendment | first = Todd | last = Spangler | date = June 2, 2020 | access-date = June 2, 2020 | work = [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | archive-date = March 2, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210302201907/https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/trump-sued-over-social-media-executive-order-first-amendment-1234623504/ | url-status = live }} The Secretary of Commerce via the NTIA sent a petition with a proposed rule to the FCC on July 27, 2020, as the first stage of executing the EO.{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/trump-administration-fcc-section-230-petition-053109450.html | title = Trump administration petitions FCC to reinterpret Section 230 rules | first = Mariella | last = Moon | date = July 27, 2020 | access-date = July 27, 2020 | work = [[Engadget]] | archive-date = January 26, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210126064313/https://www.engadget.com/trump-administration-fcc-section-230-petition-053109450.html | url-status = live }}{{cite report | url = https://www.ntia.gov/files/ntia/publications/ntia_petition_for_rulemaking_7.27.20.pdf | title = Petition For Rulemaking Of The National Telecommunications and Information Administration | publisher = [[National Telecommunications And Information Administration]] | date = July 27, 2020 | access-date = July 27, 2020 | archive-date = February 9, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210209063640/https://www.ntia.gov/files/ntia/publications/ntia_petition_for_rulemaking_7.27.20.pdf | url-status = live }} FCC chair [[Ajit Pai]] stated in October 2020 that after the Commission reviewed what authority they have over Section 230 that the FCC will proceed with putting forth their proposed rules to clarify Section 230 on October 15, 2020.{{cite web | url = https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/15/fcc-chairman-says-he-will-to-clarify-tech-legal-shield-section-230.html | title = FCC Chairman says he will move to 'clarify' Section 230, threatening tech's legal shield | first = Lauren | last = Fiener | date = October 16, 2020 | access-date = October 16, 2020 | work = [[CNBC]] | archive-date = February 24, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210224062417/https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/15/fcc-chairman-says-he-will-to-clarify-tech-legal-shield-section-230.html | url-status = live }} Pai's announcement, which came shortly after Trump again called for Section 230 revisions after asserting Big Tech was purposely hiding a [[Joe Biden 2020 presidential campaign#Trump–Ukraine scandal|reporting of leaked documents around Hunter Biden]], Joe Biden's son, was criticized by the Democratic FCC commissioners [[Geoffrey Starks]] and [[Jessica Rosenworcel]] and the tech industry, with Rosenworcel stating "The FCC has no business being the president's speech police."{{cite web |title=With 'absurd' timing, FCC announces intention to revisit Section 230 | url = https://techcrunch.com/2020/10/15/with-absurd-timing-fcc-announces-intention-to-revisit-section-230/ | first = Devin | last = Coldeway | date = October 15, 2020 | access-date = October 16, 2020 | work = [[TechCrunch]] | archive-date = February 2, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210202165955/https://techcrunch.com/2020/10/15/with-absurd-timing-fcc-announces-intention-to-revisit-section-230/ | url-status = live }}{{cite web | url = https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2020/10/15/trump-section-230-facebook-twitter-google-conservative-bias/3670858001/ | title = Trump vs. Big Tech: Everything you need to know about Section 230 and why everyone hates it | first = Jessica | last = Guynn | date = October 15, 2020 | access-date = October 16, 2020 | work = [[USA Today]] | archive-date = November 17, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201117190644/https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2020/10/15/trump-section-230-facebook-twitter-google-conservative-bias/3670858001/ | url-status = live }} A second lawsuit against the EO was filed by activist groups including [[Rock the Vote]] and [[Free Press (organization)|Free Press]] on August 27, 2020, after Twitter had flagged another of Trump's tweets for misinformation related to mail-in voting fraud. The lawsuit stated that should the EO be enforced, Twitter would not have been able to fact-check tweets like Trump's as misleading, thus allowing the President or other government officials to intentionally distribute misinformation to citizens.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/27/21404554/trump-social-media-order-section-230-rock-the-vote-free-press | title = President Trump's social media order will endanger voting rights, new lawsuit claims | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = August 27, 2020 | access-date = August 27, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = December 2, 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201202042842/https://www.theverge.com/2020/8/27/21404554/trump-social-media-order-section-230-rock-the-vote-free-press | url-status = live }} President Biden rescinded the EO on May 14, 2021, along with several of Trump's other orders.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/15/22437627/biden-revokes-trump-executive-order-section-230-twitter-facebook-google | title = Biden revokes Trump executive order that targeted Section 230 | first = Kim | last = Lyons | date = May 15, 2021 | access-date = May 15, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = May 15, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210515141814/https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/15/22437627/biden-revokes-trump-executive-order-section-230-twitter-facebook-google | url-status = live }} ====Subsequent events==== Following the [[2020 United States presidential election|November election]], Trump has made numerous claims on his social media accounts contesting the results, including claims of fraud. Twitter and other social media companies have marked these posts as potentially misleading, similar to previous posts Trump has made. As a result, Trump threatened to veto the [[William M. (Mac) Thornberry National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2021|defense spending bill for 2021]] if it did not contain language to repeal Section 230.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/trump-section-230-veto-defense-spending-bill-election-fraud-1234844020/ |title=Trump Claims He'll Veto Defense Spending Bill Unless Congress Repeals Legal Shield for Social Media Companies |first=Todd |last=Spangler |date=December 2, 2020 |access-date=December 2, 2020 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |archive-date=March 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210302012931/https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/trump-section-230-veto-defense-spending-bill-election-fraud-1234844020/ |url-status=live }} Trump made good on his promise, vetoing the spending bill on December 23, 2020, in part for not containing a repeal of Section 230.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/trump-vetoes-defense-bill-ndaa/2020/12/23/ceedffaa-407f-11eb-8db8-395dedaaa036_story.html |title=Trump vetoes defense bill, teeing up holiday override votes in Congress |first=Karoun |last=Demirjian |date=December 23, 2020 |access-date=December 23, 2020 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |archive-date=February 12, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210212195354/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/trump-vetoes-defense-bill-ndaa/2020/12/23/ceedffaa-407f-11eb-8db8-395dedaaa036_story.html |url-status=live }} The House voted to overturn the veto on December 28, 322–87, sending the bill to the Senate to vote to overturn. The Senate similarly voted to override the veto on January 1, 2021, without adding any Section 230 provisions.{{cite web |url=https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/01/politics/senate-votes-to-override-trump-veto-ndaa/index.html |title=Senate votes to override Trump's veto on defense bill |first1=Clare |last1=Foran |first2=Ted |last2=Barrett |first3=Ali |last3=Zaslav |date=January 1, 2021 |access-date=January 1, 2021 |work=[[CNN]] |archive-date=March 3, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210303235206/https://www.cnn.com/2021/01/01/politics/senate-votes-to-override-trump-veto-ndaa/index.html |url-status=live }} During this, Trump urged Congress to expand the COVID-19 relief payments in the [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2021]] that he had signed into law on December 27, 2020, but also stated that they should address the Section 230 repeal and other matters that were not addressed in the defense bill. The Senate majority leader [[Mitch McConnell]] stated on December 28 that he would bring legislation later that week that would include the expanded COVID-19 relief along with legislation to deal with Section 230, as outlined by Trump.{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/12/29/22204976/section-230-senate-deal-stimulus-talks-checks |title=Section 230 has become a bargaining chip in ongoing stimulus talks |first=Makena |last=Kelly |date=December 29, 2020 |access-date=December 29, 2020 |work=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=February 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210202210230/https://www.theverge.com/2020/12/29/22204976/section-230-senate-deal-stimulus-talks-checks |url-status=live }} Ultimately, no additional legislation was introduced. In the wake of the [[2021 United States Capitol attack]] on January 6, 2021, Pai stated that he would not be seeking any Section 230 reform before his prior planned resignation from office on January 20, 2021. Pai stated that this was mostly due to the lack of time to implement such rule making before his resignation, but also said that he would not "second-guess those decisions" of social media networks under Section 230 to block some of Trump's messages from January 6 that contributed to the violence.{{cite web |url=https://www.protocol.com/ajit-pai-distancing-trump |title=Ajit Pai is distancing himself from President Trump |first=Emily |last=Brinbrum |date=January 7, 2021 |access-date=January 8, 2021 |work=[[Protocol (website)|Protocol]] |archive-date=March 1, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210301040636/https://www.protocol.com/ajit-pai-distancing-trump |url-status=live }} In the days that followed, Twitter, Facebook, and other social media services blocked or banned Trump's accounts claiming his speech during and after the riot was inciting further violence. These actions were supported by politicians, but led to renewed calls by Democrat leaders to reconsider Section 230, as these politicians believed that Section 230 led the companies to fail to take any preemptive action against the people who had planned and executed the Capitol riots.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/01/08/facebook-twitter-congress-trump-riot/ |title=Facebook, Twitter could face punishing regulation for their role in U.S. Capitol riot, Democrats say |first=Tony |last=Romm |date=January 8, 2021 |access-date=January 10, 2021 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |archive-date=February 3, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210203212048/https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2021/01/08/facebook-twitter-congress-trump-riot/ |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/08/capitol-riot-democrats-social-media-456325 |title='This is going to come back and bite 'em': Capitol breach inflames Democrats' ire at Silicon Valley |first1=Cristiano |last1=Lima |first2=John |last2=Hendel |date=January 8, 2021 |access-date=January 10, 2021 |work=[[Politico]] |archive-date=February 18, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210218065313/https://www.politico.com/news/2021/01/08/capitol-riot-democrats-social-media-456325 |url-status=live }} Separately, Trump filed class-action lawsuits against Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube in July 2021 related to his bans from the January 2021 period, claiming their actions were unjustifable, and claiming that Section 230 was unconstitutional.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/7/22566729/trump-lawsuit-facebook-twitter-google-social-media-censorship | title = Donald Trump files sweeping, nonsensical lawsuits against Facebook, Twitter, and Google | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = July 7, 2021 | access-date = July 7, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = July 7, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210707165824/https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/7/22566729/trump-lawsuit-facebook-twitter-google-social-media-censorship | url-status = live }} Trump's lawsuit against Twitter was dismissed by a federal judge in May 2022, stating that the suit's First Amendment claims were inactionable against non-government groups like Twitter, though allowed an amended claim to be filed.{{cite news | url = https://www.cnbc.com/2022/05/06/trump-lawsuit-asking-to-lift-twitter-ban-is-dismissed.html | title = Judge dismisses Trump lawsuit seeking to lift Twitter ban | first = Dan | last = Morgan | date = May 6, 2022 | accessdate = May 14, 2022 | work = [[CNBC]] }} In March 2021, Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Alphabet's Sundar Pichai, and Twitter's Jack Dorsey were asked to testify to the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] relating to the role of social media in promoting extremism and misinformation following the 2020 election; of which Section 230 was expected to be a topic. Prior to the event, Zuckerberg proposed an alternate change to Section 230 compared to previously proposed bills. Zuckerberg stated that it would be costly and impractical for social media companies to traffic all problematic material, and instead it would be better to tie Section 230 liability protection to companies that have demonstrated that they have mechanisms in place to remove this material once it is identified.{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/3/24/22348238/zuckerberg-dorsey-pichai-section-230-hearing-misinformation |title=Mark Zuckerberg proposes limited 230 reforms ahead of congressional hearing |first=Russell |last=Brandom |date=March 24, 2021 |access-date=March 24, 2021 |work=[[The Verge]] |archive-date=March 24, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210324152220/https://www.theverge.com/2021/3/24/22348238/zuckerberg-dorsey-pichai-section-230-hearing-misinformation |url-status=live }} In July 2021, Democratic senators [[Amy Klobuchar]] and [[Ben Ray Luján]] introduced the ''Health Misinformation Act'', which is intended primarily to combat [[COVID-19 misinformation]]. It would add a carveout to Section 230 to make companies liable for the publication of "health misinformation" during a "[[Public health emergency (United States)|public health emergency]]" — as established by the [[Department of Health and Human Services]] — if the content is promoted to users via algorithmic decisions.{{Cite web|last=Kelly|first=Makena|date=2021-07-22|title=Senators target Section 230 to fight COVID-19 vaccine misinformation|url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/22/22588903/covid19-misinformation-section-230-facebook-joe-biden-white-house|access-date=2021-07-22|website=The Verge|language=en|archive-date=July 22, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210722182231/https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/22/22588903/covid19-misinformation-section-230-facebook-joe-biden-white-house|url-status=live}} ==== Justice Against Malicious Algorithms Act ==== Following [[Frances Haugen]]'s testimony to Congress that related to her [[whistleblowing]] on Facebook's internal handling of content, House Democrats [[Anna Eshoo]], [[Frank Pallone Jr.]], [[Michael F. Doyle|Mike Doyle]], and [[Jan Schakowsky]] introduced the "Justice Against Malicious Algorithms Act" in October 2021, which is in committee as [https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/5596 H.R.5596]. The bill would remove Section 230 protections for service providers related to personalized [[Recommender system|recommendation algorithms]] that present content to users if those algorithms knowingly or recklessly deliver content that contributes to physical or severe emotional injury.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/14/22726290/malicious-algorithms-section-230-bill-eshoo-pallone-doyle-schakowsky-facebook-whistleblower | title = Lawmakers want to strip legal protections from the Facebook News Feed | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = October 14, 2021 | access-date = October 14, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = October 14, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20211014170451/https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/14/22726290/malicious-algorithms-section-230-bill-eshoo-pallone-doyle-schakowsky-facebook-whistleblower | url-status = live }} ''“The last few years have proven that the more outrageous and extremist content social media platforms promote, the more engagement and advertising dollars they rake in'',” said Representative Frank Pallone Jr., the chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee. “''By now it’s painfully clear that neither the market nor public pressure will stop social media companies from elevating disinformation and extremism, so we have no choice but to legislate, and now it’s a question of how best to do it'',” he added.{{Cite news |last=McCabe |first=David |date=2021-03-24 |title=How a Stabbing in Israel Echoes Through the Fight Over Online Speech |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/24/technology/section-230-hearing-facebook.html |access-date=2022-10-04 |issn=0362-4331}} ====State laws ==== ===== Florida ===== The state of Florida (predominantly Republican after the 2020 election) passed its "deplatforming" Senate Bill 7072 in May 2021, which had been proposed in February 2021 after Trump had been banned from several social media sites. SB 7072 prevents social media companies from knowingly blocking or banning politicians, and grants the [[Florida Elections Commission]] the ability to fine these companies for knowing violations, with fines as high as {{USD|250,000|long=no}} per day for state-level politicians. The bill exempts companies that own theme parks or other large venues within the state, thus would exempt companies such as [[Disney]] whose parks provide a significant tax revenue to the state.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/24/22451425/florida-social-media-moderation-facebook-twitter-deplatforming | title = Florida governor signs law to block 'deplatforming' of Florida politicians | first = Makena | last = Kelly | date = May 24, 2021 | access-date = May 24, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = May 24, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210524170650/https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/24/22451425/florida-social-media-moderation-facebook-twitter-deplatforming | url-status = live }} The [[Computer & Communications Industry Association]] (CCIA) and NetChoice filed suit against the state to block enforcement of the law, in Netchoice v. Moody, asserting that the law violated the First Amendment rights of private companies.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/27/22457200/ccia-netchoice-lawsuit-florida-social-media-law-unconstitutional | title = Industry groups sue to stop Florida's new social media law | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = May 27, 2021 | access-date = May 28, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = May 27, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210527215438/https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/27/22457200/ccia-netchoice-lawsuit-florida-social-media-law-unconstitutional | url-status = live }} Judge [[Robert Lewis Hinkle]] of the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Florida]] issued a preliminary injunction against the law on June 30, 2021, stating that "The legislation now at issue was an effort to rein in social-media providers deemed too large and too liberal. Balancing the exchange of ideas among private speakers is not a legitimate governmental interest", and further that the law "discriminates on its face among otherwise identical speakers".{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/30/22558086/florida-social-media-theme-park-law-preliminary-injunction-lawsuit | title = Judge blocks Florida's social media law | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = June 30, 2021 | access-date = June 30, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = July 1, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210701010316/https://www.theverge.com/2021/6/30/22558086/florida-social-media-theme-park-law-preliminary-injunction-lawsuit | url-status = live }} ===== Texas ===== [[Texas H.B. 20]], enacted in September 2021, intended to prevent large social media providers from banning or demonetizing their users based on the user's viewpoint, including for views expressed outside of the social media platform, as well as to increase transparency in how these providers moderate content.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/9/9/22661626/texas-social-media-law-hb-20-signed-greg-abbott | title = Texas passes law that bans kicking people off social media based on 'viewpoint' | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = September 9, 2021 | access-date = September 9, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = September 9, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210909214635/https://www.theverge.com/2021/9/9/22661626/texas-social-media-law-hb-20-signed-greg-abbott | url-status = live }} The CCIA and NetChoice filed suit to prevent enforcement of the law in [[NetChoice v. Paxton]]. A federal district judge placed an injunction on this law in December 2021, stating that the law's "prohibitions on 'censorship' and constraints on how social media platforms disseminate content violate the First Amendment".{{Cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2021/12/1/22809654/texas-law-blocked-netchoice-ccia-injunction-viewpoint-discrimination | title = Federal court blocks Texas law banning 'viewpoint discrimination' on social media | first1 = Adi | last1 = Robertson | first2 = Russell | last2 = Brandom | date = December 1, 2021 | access-date = December 1, 2021 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = December 2, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20211202024230/https://www.theverge.com/2021/12/1/22809654/texas-law-blocked-netchoice-ccia-injunction-viewpoint-discrimination | url-status = live }} However, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|Fifth Circuit]] reversed the injunction on a 2–1 order without yet ruling on the merits of the case in May 2022, effectively allowing the Texas law to come into effect.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/11/23067002/texas-netchoice-paxton-hb20-social-media-law-fifth-circuit-appeals-court-grant-stay-ruling | title = Court lets Texas restrictions on social platform content moderation take effect | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = May 11, 2022 | accessdate = May 11, 2022 | work = [[The Verge]] }} The CCIA and NetChoice appealed the Fifth Circuit decision directly to the U.S. Supreme Court seeking an emergency injunction to block the law. They argued that regulations on how social media platforms moderate users' content may prevent them from moderating at all in certain situations and thus force them to publish material they find objectionable, an outcome that would violate the social media platforms' First Amendment rights.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/13/23072310/netchoice-texas-social-media-law-supreme-court-appeal | title = Tech industry appeals the bad Texas social media law to the Supreme Court | first = Sarah | last = Jeong | date = May 13, 2022 | accessdate = May 14, 2022 | work = [[The Verge]] }} On May 31, 2022, the Supreme Court restored the injunction by court order (with four Justices, [[Samuel Alito]], [[Clarence Thomas]], [[Elena Kagan]], and [[Neil Gorsuch]] dissenting) while lower court litigation continued.{{cite web | url = https://www.engadget.com/scotus-texas-moderation-law-platforms-hb20-231226107.html?src=rss | title = Texas's bizarre social media law suspended by Supreme Court | first =Bryan | last = Menegus | date = May 31, 2022 | accessdate = May 31, 2022 | work = [[Engadget]] }} The Fifth Circuit reversed the district court ruling in September 2022, with Judge [[Andy Oldham]] stating in the majority opinion, "Today we reject the idea that corporations have a freewheeling First Amendment right to censor what people say." The decision creates a [[circuit split]] with the potential to be heard by the Supreme Court.{{cite news | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/09/16/5th-circuit-texas-social-media-law/ |title = Appeals court upholds Texas law regulating social media moderation | first = Cat | last = Zakrzewski | date = September 16, 2022 | accessdate = September 16, 2022 | newspaper = [[Washington Post]] }} The Fifth Circuit agreed to rejoin enforcement if the law in October 2022 while several tech companies petitioned the case to the Supreme Court.{{cite web | url=https://amp.cnn.com/cnn/2022/10/13/tech/texas-social-media-pause/index.html | title=Federal appeals court pauses Texas social media law's enforcement amid looming Supreme Court petition }} ===== California ===== {{Expand section|date=October 2022}} ==Case law== Numerous cases involving Section 230 have been heard in the judiciary system since its introduction, many which are rote applications of Section 230. The following is a partial list of legal cases that have been established as [[case law]] that have influenced the interpretation of Section 230 in subsequent cases or have led to new legislation around Section 230. ===Defamatory information=== ; ''Zeran v. AOL'', 129 F.3d 327 (4th Cir. 1997).[http://pacer.ca4.uscourts.gov/opinion.pdf/971523.P.pdf ''Zeran v. AOL''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081031132904/http://pacer.ca4.uscourts.gov/opinion.pdf/971523.P.pdf |date=October 31, 2008 }}, 129 F.3d 327 (4th Cir. 1997). : Immunity was '''''upheld''''' against claims that [[AOL]] unreasonably delayed in removing defamatory messages posted by third party, failed to post retractions, and failed to screen for similar postings. ; ''Blumenthal v. [[Matt Drudge|Drudge]]'', 992 F. Supp. 44, 49–53 (D.D.C. 1998).[http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/property00/jurisdiction/blumenthal.html ''Blumenthal v. Drudge''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511213411/http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/property00/jurisdiction/blumenthal.html |date=May 11, 2008 }}, 992 F. Supp. 44, 49–53 (D.D.C. 1998). : The court '''''upheld''''' AOL's immunity from liability for defamation. AOL's agreement with the contractor allowing AOL to modify or remove such content did not make AOL the "information content provider" because the content was created by an independent contractor. The Court noted that Congress made a policy choice by "providing immunity even where the interactive service provider has an active, even aggressive role in making available content prepared by others." ; ''[[Carafano v. Metrosplash.com]]'', 339 F.3d 1119 (9th Cir. 2003).[http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/ca9/newopinions.nsf/23FE0B8E8A5093C188256D810068FB6F/%24file/0255658.pdf ''Carafano v. Metrosplash.com''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060218163209/http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/ca9/newopinions.nsf/23FE0B8E8A5093C188256D810068FB6F/%24file/0255658.pdf |date=February 18, 2006 }}, 339 F.3d 1119 (9th Cir. 2003). : The court '''''upheld''''' immunity for an Internet dating service provider from liability stemming from third party's submission of a false profile. The plaintiff, [[Chase Masterson|Carafano]], claimed the false profile defamed her, but because the content was created by a third party, the website was immune, even though it had provided multiple choice selections to aid profile creation. ; ''Batzel v. Smith'', 333 F.3d 1018 (9th Cir. 2003).[https://web.archive.org/web/20100517182228/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/333/333.F3d.1018.01-56556.01-56380.html ''Batzel v. Smith''], 333 F.3d 1018 (9th Cir. 2003). : Immunity was '''''upheld''''' for a website operator for distributing an email to a listserv where the plaintiff claimed the email was defamatory. Though there was a question as to whether the information provider intended to send the email to the listserv, the Court decided that for determining the liability of the service provider, "the focus should be not on the information provider's intentions or knowledge when transmitting content but, instead, on the service provider's or user's reasonable perception of those intentions or knowledge." The Court found immunity proper "under circumstances in which a reasonable person in the position of the service provider or user would conclude that the information was provided for publication on the Internet or other 'interactive computer service'." ; ''Green v. AOL'', 318 F.3d 465 (3rd Cir. 2003).[http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/318/318.F3d.465.01-1120.html ''Green v. Green claimed AOL failed to adequately police its services and allowed third parties to defame him and inflict intentional emotional distress. The court rejected these arguments because holding AOL negligent in promulgating harmful content would be equivalent to holding AOL "liable for decisions relating to the monitoring, screening, and deletion of content from its network -- actions quintessentially related to a publisher's role." ; ''[[Barrett v. The court found the defendant to be a "user of interactive computer services" and thus immune from liability for posting information passed to her by the author. ; ''MCW, Inc. v. badbusinessbureau.com(RipOff Report/Ed Magedson/XCENTRIC Ventures LLC)'' 2004 WL 833595, No. Civ.A.3:02-CV-2727-G (N.D. Tex. April 19, 2004). : The court '''''rejected''''' the defendant's motion to dismiss on the grounds of Section 230 immunity, ruling that the plaintiff's allegations that the defendants wrote disparaging report titles and headings, and themselves wrote disparaging editorial messages about the plaintiff, rendered them information content providers. The Web site, www.badbusinessbureau.com, allows users to upload "reports" containing complaints about businesses they have dealt with. ; ''Hy Cite Corp. v. badbusinessbureau.com (RipOff Report/Ed Magedson/XCENTRIC Ventures LLC)'', 418 F. Supp. 2d 1142] (D. While the Ninth Circuit ultimately dismissed the case since Yahoo! would not have been liable for the photos under Section 230, their promissory estoppel makes them a "publisher or speaker" under Section 230. ===False information=== ; ''Gentry v. eBay, Inc.'', 99 Cal. Roommates.com, LLC'', 521 F.3d 1157 (9th Cir. 2008) (''en banc'').[http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2008/04/02/0456916.pdf ''Fair Housing Council of San Fernando Valley v. The court concluded that the manner in which the service elicited required information from users concerning their roommate preferences (by having dropdowns specifying gender, presence of children, and sexual orientation), and the manner in which it utilized that information in generating roommate matches (by eliminating profiles that did not match user specifications), that the service was an "information content provider" and thus liable for the discrimination claims. The court '''''upheld''''' immunity for the descriptions posted by users in the "Additional Comments" section because these were entirely created by users.{{cite journal | title = The Gradual Erosion of the Law That Shaped the Internet: Section 230s Evolution Over Two Decades | first = Jeff | last= Kosseff | journal = Columbia Science and Technology Law Review | volume = 18 | number = 1| date = 2017 | ssrn = 3225774 }} ===Threats=== ; ''Delfino v. [[Agilent Technologies]]'', 145 Cal. App. 4th 790 (2006), cert denied, 128 S. Ct. 98 (2007). : A California Appellate Court unanimously '''''upheld''''' immunity from state tort claims arising from an employee's use of the employer's e-mail system to send threatening messages. The court concluded that an employer that provides Internet access to its employees qualifies as a "provider ... of an interactive service." ===Failure to warn=== ; ''[[Jane Doe No. 14 v. Internet Brands, Inc.]]'', No. 12-56638 (9th Cir. September 17, 2014). : The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals '''''rejected''''' immunity for claims of negligence under California law. : Doe filed a complaint against Internet Brands which alleged a "failure to warn" her of a known rape scheme, despite her relationship to them as a ModelMayhem.com member. They also had requisite knowledge to avoid future victimization of ModelMayhem.com users by warning users of online sexual predators. The Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals concluded that the Communications Decency Act did not bar the claim and remanded the case to the district court for further proceedings. : In February 2015, the Ninth Circuit panel set aside its 2014 opinion and set the case for reargument. In May 2016, the panel again held that Doe's case could proceed.{{cite news |last1=Proctor |first1=Katherine |title=Raped Model's Suit Against Website Revived |url=http://www.courthousenews.com/2016/05/31/raped-models-suit-against-website-revived.htm |access-date=June 1, 2016 |publisher=Courthouse News Service |date=May 31, 2016 |archive-date=October 7, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161007145100/http://www.courthousenews.com/2016/05/31/raped-models-suit-against-website-revived.htm |url-status=live }}''[https://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/opinions/2016/05/31/12-56638.pdf Jane Doe No. 14 v. May 31, 2016). ===Terrorism=== ; ''[[Force v. Facebook Inc.|Force v. Facebook, Inc.]]'', 934 F.3d 53 (2nd Cir. 2019). : The Second Circuit '''''upheld''''' immunity in civil claims for service providers for hosting terrorism-related content created by users. Families, friends, and associates of several killed in [[Hamas]] attacks filed suit against Facebook under the United States' Anti-Terrorism Act, asserting that since Hamas members used Facebook to coordinate activities, Facebook was liable for its content. While previous rules at federal District and Circuit level have generally ruled against such cases, this decision in the Second Circuit was first to assert that Section 230 does apply even to acts related to terrorism that may be posted by users of service providers, thus dismissing the suit against Facebook. The Second Circuit ruled that the various algorithms Facebook for its [[recommender system]] remain as part of the role of the distributor of the content and not the publisher, since these automated tools were essentially neutral.{{cite web | url = https://www.natlawreview.com/article/facebook-shielded-cda-immunity-against-federal-claims-allowing-use-its-platform | title = Facebook Shielded by CDA Immunity against Federal Claims for Allowing Use of Its Platform by Terrorists | first = Jeffrey | last = Neuburger | date = August 9, 2019 | access-date = August 14, 2019 | work = [[National Law Review]] | archive-date = January 7, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210107173455/https://www.natlawreview.com/article/facebook-shielded-cda-immunity-against-federal-claims-allowing-use-its-platform | url-status = live }} The Supreme Court declined to hear the case.{{cite web | url = https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/18/21262248/supreme-court-rejects-stuart-force-facebook-section-230-lawsuit-algorithms | title = Supreme Court rejects lawsuit against Facebook for hosting terrorists | first = Adi | last = Robertson | date = May 18, 2020 | access-date = May 18, 2020 | work = [[The Verge]] | archive-date = January 30, 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210130004435/https://www.theverge.com/2020/5/18/21262248/supreme-court-rejects-stuart-force-facebook-section-230-lawsuit-algorithms | url-status = live }} : Judge [[Robert Katzmann|Robert Katzman]] gave a 35-page dissenting opinion in the Force case, which was cited by Justice [[Clarence Thomas]] in a suggestion to colleagues in 2020 to reconsider the scope of immunity granted under Section 230.{{Cite news |last=McCabe |first=David |date=2021-03-24 |title=How a Stabbing in Israel Echoes Through the Fight Over Online Speech |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/03/24/technology/section-230-hearing-facebook.html |access-date=2022-10-04 |issn=0362-4331}} ;''[[Gonzalez v. Google LLC]]'' (2023) and ''[[Twitter, Inc. v. Taamneh]]'' (2023) :Both cases were ruled on by the Supreme Court in May 2023. In ''Gonzalez'', YouTube, via Google was accused of aiding terrorism by its recommendation algorithm, which Google claimed immunity via Section 230.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2022/10/03/us/supreme-court-social-media-section-230.html | title = Supreme Court Takes Up Challenge to Social Media Platforms' Shield | first1 = Adam | last1 = Liptak | first2 = Dave | last2 = McCabe | date = October 3, 2022 | accessdate = October 3, 2022 | work = [[The New York Times]] }} In ''Twitter'', Twitter and other social media companies were argued to have assisted in terrorist activity under the [[Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996]] amended by the [[Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act]]. Twitter tried to argue for Section 230 immunity but this was not considered in lower courts.{{Cite web |last=Robertson |first=Adi |date=2022-10-03 |title=The Supreme Court will determine whether you can sue platforms for hosting terrorists |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/10/3/23385019/supreme-court-grants-petitions-google-twitter-section-230-terrorism |access-date=2022-10-04 |website=The Verge |language=en-US}} in the Supreme Court decision for ''Twitter'', the unanimous court ruled that there were no actionable charges against Twitter under the Antiterrorism Act; the plaintiff family failed to state a claim for relief. Subsequently, the ''Gonzalez'' case was return by per curium order to lower courts to review the case in light of the ''Twitter'' decision. These decisions effectively avoided raising any questions in Section 230.{{Cite web |last=Fung |first=Brian |date=2023-05-18 |title=Supreme Court shields Twitter from liability for terror-related content and leaves Section 230 untouched |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/05/18/politics/supreme-court-twitter-google-social-media/index.html |access-date=2023-05-18 |website=CNN Politics |language=en}} ==Similar legislation in other countries== ===European Union=== [[Directive 2000/31/EC]],{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32000L0031:EN:HTML|title=EUR-Lex - 32000L0031 - EN|work=europa.eu|access-date=April 16, 2009|archive-date=February 20, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210220221848/https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX%3A32000L0031%3AEN%3AHTML|url-status=live}} the e-Commerce Directive, establishes a safe harbor regime for hosting providers: * Article 14 establishes that hosting providers are not responsible for the content they host as long as (1) the acts in question are neutral intermediary acts of a mere technical, automatic and passive capacity; (2) they are not informed of its illegal character, and (3) they act promptly to remove or disable access to the material when informed of it. * Article 15 precludes member states from imposing general obligations to monitor hosted content for potential illegal activities. The updated [[Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market]] (Directive 2019/790) Article 17 makes providers liable if they fail to take "effective and proportionate measures" to prevent users from uploading certain copyright violations and do not respond immediately to takedown requests.{{cite web|url=http://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/35373/st09134-en18.pdf|title=Proposal for a directive on copyright in the Digital Single Market|date=May 25, 2018|page=26|access-date=March 12, 2019|archive-date=June 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180609084910/http://www.consilium.europa.eu/media/35373/st09134-en18.pdf|url-status=live}} ===Australia=== In ''Dow Jones & Company Inc v Gutnick'',{{cite web|url=http://www.kentlaw.edu/perritt/courses/civpro/Dow%20Jones%20&%20Company%20Inc_%20v%20Gutnick%20%5B2002%5D%20HCA%2056%20(10%20December%202002).htm|title=Dow Jones & Company Inc. v Gutnick [2002] HCA 56 (10 December 2002)|work=kentlaw.edu|access-date=December 15, 2021|archive-date=December 4, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201204175634/http://www.kentlaw.edu/perritt/courses/civpro/Dow%20Jones%20%26%20Company%20Inc_%20v%20Gutnick%20%5B2002%5D%20HCA%2056%20%2810%20December%202002%29.htm|url-status=live}} the High Court of Australia treated defamatory material on a server outside Australia as having been published in Australia when it is downloaded or read by someone in Australia. ''Gorton v Australian Broadcasting Commission & Anor'' (1973) 1 ACTR 6 Under the ''Defamation Act 2005'' (NSW),{{cite web|url=http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/da200599/|title=DEFAMATION ACT 2005|work=austlii.edu.au|access-date=March 12, 2009|archive-date=December 12, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201212040846/http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/nsw/consol_act/da200599/|url-status=live}} s 32, a defence to defamation is that the defendant neither knew, nor ought reasonably to have known of the defamation, and the lack of knowledge was not due to the defendant's negligence. ===Italy=== The [[Electronic Commerce Directive 2000]] (e-Commerce Directive) has been implemented in Italy by means of Legislative Decree no. 70 of 2003. The provisions provided by Italy are substantially in line with those provided at the EU level. However, at the beginning, the Italian case-law had drawn a line between so-called "active" hosting providers and "passive" Internet Service Providers, arguing that "active" Internet Service Providers would not benefit from the liability exception provided by Legislative Decree no. 70. According to that case-law, an ISP is deemed to be active whenever it carries out operations on the content provided by the user, such as in case it modifies the content or makes any enrichment of the content. Under certain cases, courts have held ISPs liable for the user's content for the mere facts that such content was somehow organised or enriched by the ISP (e.g. by organizing the contents in libraries or categories, etc. or monetised by showing ads). ===New Zealand=== Failing to investigate the material or to make inquiries of the user concerned may amount to negligence in this context: ''Jensen v Clark'' [1982] 2 NZLR 268. ===France=== Directive 2000/31/CE was transposed into the [[:fr:Loi pour la confiance dans l'économie numérique|LCEN]] law. Article 6 of the law establishes safe haven for hosting provider as long as they follow certain rules. In ''[[LICRA vs. Yahoo!]]'', the High Court ordered Yahoo! to take affirmative steps to filter out Nazi memorabilia from its auction site. Yahoo!, Inc. and its then president [[Timothy Koogle]] were also criminally charged, but acquitted. ===Germany=== In 1997, [[Felix Somm]], the former managing director for CompuServe Germany, was charged with violating German [[child pornography]] laws because of the material CompuServe's network was carrying into Germany. He was convicted and sentenced to two years probation on May 28, 1998.{{cite web |url=http://www.gseis.ucla.edu/iclp/fsomm.html |title=The CompuServe Germany Case |access-date=November 23, 2003 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040225201934/http://www.gseis.ucla.edu/iclp/fsomm.html |archive-date=February 25, 2004 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.kuner.com/data/reg/somm.html |title=Judgment of the Munich Court in the "CompuServe Case" (Somm Case) |author=Christopher Kuner |access-date=March 12, 2009 |archive-date=March 3, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303180621/http://www.kuner.com/data/reg/somm.html |url-status=live }} He was cleared on appeal on November 17, 1999.{{cite web |url=http://www.digital-law.net/somm/commentary.html |title=Commentary on the Conclusion of Proceedings in the "CompuServe Case" |author=PROF. DR. ULRICH SIEBER |access-date=March 12, 2009 |archive-date=December 5, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151205025604/http://www.digital-law.net/somm/commentary.html |url-status=live }}{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/524951.stm |title=World: Europe Ex-CompuServe boss acquitted |date=November 17, 1999 |website=BBC |access-date=March 12, 2009 |archive-date=December 3, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203211717/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/524951.stm |url-status=live }} The Oberlandesgericht (OLG) Cologne, an appellate court, found that an online auctioneer does not have an active duty to check for counterfeit goods (Az 6 U 12/01).{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/BGH-Online-Auktionshaeuser-muessen-Angebote-von-Plagiaten-sperren--/meldung/45495|title=BGH: Online-Auktionshäuser müssen Angebote von Plagiaten sperren|author=Noogie C. Kaufmann|date=March 12, 2004|work=heise online|access-date=March 12, 2009|archive-date=April 14, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080414192148/http://www.heise.de/newsticker/BGH-Online-Auktionshaeuser-muessen-Angebote-von-Plagiaten-sperren--/meldung/45495|url-status=live}} In one example, the first-instance district court of Hamburg issued a temporary restraining order requiring message board operator Universal Boards to review all comments before they can be posted to prevent the publication of messages inciting others to download harmful files. The court reasoned that "the publishing house must be held liable for spreading such material in the forum, regardless of whether it was aware of the content."{{cite web|url=http://www.heise.de/english/newsticker/news/67029|title=heise online - IT-News, Nachrichten und Hintergründe|work=heise online|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081022072256/http://www.heise.de/english/newsticker/news/67029|archive-date=October 22, 2008}} ===United Kingdom=== {{See also|Defamation Act 2013}} The laws of libel and defamation will treat a disseminator of information as having "published" material posted by a user, and the onus will then be on a defendant to prove that it did not know the publication was defamatory and was not negligent in failing to know: ''Goldsmith v Sperrings Ltd'' (1977) 2 All ER 566; ''Vizetelly v Mudie's Select Library Ltd'' (1900) 2 QB 170; ''Emmens v Pottle & Ors'' (1885) 16 QBD 354. In an action against a website operator, on a statement posted on the website, it is a defence to show that it was not the operator who posted the statement on the website. The defence is defeated if it was not possible for the claimant to identify the person who posted the statement, or the claimant gave the operator a notice of complaint and the operator failed to respond in accordance with regulations. ==See also== {{Portal|United States|Politics|Law|Internet}} * [[Collateral censorship]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.7591/j.ctvr7fcrd|title=The Twenty-Six Words That Created the Internet|first=Jeff|last=Kosseff|author-link=Jeff Kosseff|year=2019|publisher=[[Cornell University Press]]|jstor=10.7591/j.ctvr7fcrd|isbn=978-1501735783}} * {{usc|47|230}} * Margaret Jane Radin et al., ''Internet Commerce: The Emerging Legal Framework'' 1091-1136 (2nd ed. 2006) * [[The Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] - Article 12 * [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]] - Article 17 (1), (2) * [http://hrlibrary.umn.edu/usdocs/civilres.html U.S. reservations, declarations, and understandings, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, 138 Cong.
